processedVideos.transcriptText:
What can Indian clubs do for you?

Gently mobilizes the shoulders, elbows and wrists and improve range of motion

Strengthens the shoulder girdle and grip ( muscles and connective tissues) in its full range of motion

Consists of compound movements in multiple planes

Provides low impact cardiovascular exercise

Assists recovery from intense training

Improves the 3 pillars of physical literacy (body control , locomotion and object control)

It is fun and you forget you are training.

The rhythmic and repetitive patterns are highly meditative and calm the nervous system, like meditation.

Cross crawl exercises and other challenging moves improve learning capacity and stimulate neurogenesis, the creation of new brain cells.

❂ Heroic Sport | An ancient discipline

Our clubs are easily adjustable, which is a modern twist on the ancient traditional Indian clubs used to train Tamil and Persian warriors and wrestlers.

Indian clubs were used in Europe and USA for remedial gymnastics in the 18th and 19th century, by pioneers of physiotherapy.

single outer heart-shaped swing stand with your feet under your shoulders from the top let the club fall away from your body swing past your face then over and behind your shoulder open your elbow to the side and launch the club as high as possible keep the swing close to your body and vertical to the floor as possible stand tall do not Bend forward let your hips and shoulders rotate with the direction of the swing lift and launch the club towards the ceiling with your arm fully bent swing across your shoulders open up your elbow to the side do not twist your wrists to make this circle to help you use the four count swing go slow and Mark each position 1. 2. three poor the colored batch shows the rotation

# [Indian clubs 102 Lesson 2/20: single outer heart shaped swing](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=BKz6hsnog4s)

**Visibility**: Public
**Uploaded by**: [Heroic Sport - Indian clubs workouts](http://www.youtube.com/@HeroicSport)
**Uploaded at**: 2023-03-18T00:28:45-07:00
**Published at**: 2023-03-18T00:28:45-07:00
**Length**: 03:15
**Views**: 2016
**Likes**: 46
**Category**: Sports

## Description

```
---
What can Indian clubs do for you?
Watch this: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ft-FL_6s_No

❂ Physical benefits
Gently mobilizes the shoulders, elbows and wrists and improve range of motion
Strengthens the shoulder girdle and grip ( muscles and connective tissues) in its full range of motion
Consists of compound movements in multiple planes
Provides low impact cardiovascular exercise
Assists recovery from intense training
Improves the 3 pillars of physical literacy (body control , locomotion and object control)

❂ Mental benefits
It is fun and you forget you are training.
The rhythmic and repetitive patterns are highly meditative and calm the nervous system, like meditation.
Cross crawl exercises and other challenging moves improve learning capacity and stimulate neurogenesis, the creation of new brain cells.

❂ Heroic Sport | An ancient discipline 
We have created the Pahlavandle ™ range to make it affordable for everyone to discover the benefits of swinging clubs.
Our clubs are easily adjustable, which is a modern twist on the ancient traditional Indian clubs used to train Tamil and Persian warriors and wrestlers. 
Indian clubs were used in Europe and USA for remedial gymnastics in the 18th and 19th century, by pioneers of physiotherapy.
```

## Transcript

single outer heart-shaped swing stand with your feet under your shoulders from the top let the club fall away from your body swing past your face then over and behind your shoulder open your elbow to the side and launch the club as high as possible keep the swing close to your body and vertical to the floor as possible stand tall do not Bend forward let your hips and shoulders rotate with the direction of the swing lift and launch the club towards the ceiling with your arm fully bent swing across your shoulders open up your elbow to the side do not twist your wrists to make this circle to help you use the four count swing go slow and Mark each position 1. 2. three poor the colored batch shows the rotation

processedVideos.transcriptText:
Circuit training with Indian clubs is a great way to train a multitude of movements in a short time to break from doing the same thing over and over.

Thierry shows you a  5  minute circuit with 10 exercises done for 30 seconds each.

We combine basic elements we have covered previously plus some new moves.

Repeat the circuit as needed, according to fitness levels and time.

You can create infinite circuits, combining different training modalities, like bodyweight exercises, rope skipping, kettlebells and such. Get the pulse up, it's all good.

What can Indian clubs do for you?

Gently mobilizes the shoulders, elbows and wrists and improve range of motion

Strengthens the shoulder girdle and grip ( muscles and connective tissues) in its full range of motion

Consists of compound movements in multiple planes

Provides low impact cardiovascular exercise

Assists recovery from intense training

Improves the 3 pillars of physical literacy (body control , locomotion and object control)

It is fun and you forget you are training.

The rhythmic and repetitive patterns are highly meditative and calm the nervous system, like meditation.

Cross crawl exercises and other challenging moves improve learning capacity and stimulate neurogenesis, the creation of new brain cells.

❂ Heroic Sport | An ancient discipline

Our clubs are easily adjustable, which is a modern twist on the ancient traditional Indian clubs used to train Tamil and Persian warriors and wrestlers.

Indian clubs were used in Europe and USA for remedial gymnastics in the 18th and 19th century, by pioneers of physiotherapy.

training with this open style of Club swinging and training with relatively light clubs the goal is on longevity and feeling good increasing your well-being and energy levels so one way to gauge if you're training has been correct for you is the way you feel after the training yeah if you feel better than you did before you start training then it's done its job that's it you don't need to do any ## Description

```
Circuit training with Indian clubs is a great way to train a multitude of movements in a short time to break from doing the same thing over and over.

Thierry shows you a  5  minute circuit with 10 exercises done for 30 seconds each. 
We combine basic elements we have covered previously plus some new moves. 
Repeat the circuit as needed, according to fitness levels and time.

You can create infinite circuits, combining different training modalities, like bodyweight exercises, rope skipping, kettlebells and such. Get the pulse up, it's all good.

---
What can Indian clubs do for you?
Watch this: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ft-FL_6s_No

❂ Physical benefits
Gently mobilizes the shoulders, elbows and wrists and improve range of motion
Strengthens the shoulder girdle and grip ( muscles and connective tissues) in its full range of motion
Consists of compound movements in multiple planes
Provides low impact cardiovascular exercise
Assists recovery from intense training
Improves the 3 pillars of physical literacy (body control , locomotion and object control)

❂ Mental benefits
It is fun and you forget you are training.
The rhythmic and repetitive patterns are highly meditative and calm the nervous system, like meditation.
Cross crawl exercises and other challenging moves improve learning capacity and stimulate neurogenesis, the creation of new brain cells.

❂ Heroic Sport | An ancient discipline 
We have created the Pahlavandle ™ range to make it affordable for everyone to discover the benefits of swinging clubs.
Our clubs are easily adjustable, which is a modern twist on the ancient traditional Indian clubs used to train Tamil and Persian warriors and wrestlers. 
Indian clubs were used in Europe and USA for remedial gymnastics in the 18th and 19th century, by pioneers of physiotherapy.
```

processedVideos.transcriptText:
Indian clubs can help your HEMA skills, as long as you do not just replicate sword attacks with clubs...

In this video, Thierry shows the 2 ways to perform wrist circles, depending on the weight of the club and goals. Are you just swinging clubs for general health and conditioning, or do you practice HEMA? Let us know in the comments!

Visit our website to learn how to swing Indian clubs step by step.

CHECK OUT THOSE LINKS

WHY YOU SHOULD SWING INDIAN CLUBS

Gently mobilizes the shoulders, elbows and wrists and improve range of motion

Strengthens the shoulder girdle and grip ( muscles and connective tissues) in its full range of motion

Consists of compound movements in multiple planes

Provides low impact cardiovascular exercise

Assists recovery from intense training

Improves the 3 pillars of physical literacy (body control , locomotion and object control)

It is fun and you forget you are training.

The rhythmic and repetitive patterns are highly meditative and calm the nervous system, like meditation.

Cross crawl exercises and other challenging moves improve learning capacity and stimulate neurogenesis, the creation of new brain cells.

❂ HEROIC SPORT | AN ANCIENT SPORT

Our clubs are easily adjustable, which is a modern twist on the ancient traditional Indian clubs used to train Tamil and Persian warriors.

Indian clubs were used in Europe and USA for remedial gymnastics in the 18th and 19th century, by pioneers of physiotherapy.

❂ READY TO LEARN MORE?

All our educational material has been tested and structured since 2010, in a way that is easy for anyone to learn from home.

Best regards from Thierry & Ron

hey terry from eric sport welcome to the channel so today we're going to take a look at wrist circles with indian clubs for hema some people hate the indian clubs for hammer some people love them i think we just need to separate you know the ancient tradition of what they were designed for in the first place training warriors wrestlers and so on so martial arts application and the more modern more recent visual performance application of indian clubs so let's be on the same page most people would associate indian clubs with this type of clubs okay either bottle shape or teardrop shape that were introduced by the british in europe around the 1800s and basically those clubs i'm back they can weigh anything from half a kilo to two kilos now two kilos in india for an indian club or mod gar or mock doll or whatever variation of the name you can think of would be a very light club the warriors and the wrestlers train with large bulky and heavy clubs or maces for the most okay so this club here for example is a 5.5 kilo club and to top it up it's got a really thick grip so i'm not just going to twirl it and make the okay sign because that's definitely not going to be okay it's going on the floor so you can see what's happening here i'm holding my full grip and this is basically the type of grip i would recommend if you are into hema however most adults are lacking the mobility around the wrist to be able to perform smooth wrist circles so the recommended option what i choose for when i'm teaching people is to learn the ring grip so start with that so you can get a feel for the wrist circles so it doesn't look clunky and always start with one you know and then you can start of linking them okay so this is fine yeah and then eventually you want to start like keeping the full grip without you know the white knuckle death grip on the on the club otherwise you're gonna tense up the whole arm and you can't really move that club okay so the ring grip is a fine way to get started to learn the movement and you know you can make those circles in both directions of course but then you want to sort of like graduate to being able to do them with a full grip so with the large heavy clubs most of the moves are based on attacks and by attacks i mean by moves where you cross the midline because that's our strongest uh movement pattern yeah so going away from the midline would be like akin to throwing a dart whereas you know crossing the midline you know you're sword fighting okay boom throwing a spare uh throwing an axe wrestling arm wrestling you know the winner is the guy that crosses the midline this is where we're strong and you lose by going away from the midline so the light clubs open different type of patterns you can do them you know very fancy linking all this kind of stuff but we went from you know the purpose of the indian club that was to train fighters and wrestlers to more of a spectator sport visual performance and this is where the clubs got lighter so you can do new patterns by changing grips you know doing the snakes and all this kind of stuff and it's very available for dexterity and stuff you know but if you're training for a hammer the full grip is the way to go doing the wrist circles with the full grip require more awareness mobility and coordination than using the ring grip okay so you have to practice and when you practice you don't want a stupidly heavy club okay now this club here is our palavendor gamma it's got a 40mm handle so it's still a very thick handle you can see like i'm just closing it here and this is what the forward wrist circle looks like now when we say wrist circle it's actually the club doing a circle because our wrist if you observe now is doing a type of rolling motion okay and the same when i go in reverse so when you practice you know you gotta figure out you gotta imagine you got a wall next to you so the club stays as perpendicular to the ground as possible while your elbow comes in towards the midline as the club drop okay so pay attention to the hand position how much it goes up and down and the displacement towards the midline from my elbow yeah and then you can sort of like do fun stuff and i'm hauling the full grip okay so the full grip we've got two variations you could say you've got the hammer grip yeah perpendicular and this would be used as a resting position or transition position and then you've got the saber grip where the handle of the club is in the proponention of your forearm and kind of like all those moves around there using the saber grip okay so for hema they're the two main groups you need to master worry about and just have a firm grip but relaxed enough to be able to transition between those movements okay also important that you will build some strength by doing wrist circles which also do some direct work to strengthen your wrist and your fingers and your hands in general and again i'll put a link in the description to a circuit where you just follow along to a couple of times a week works great also if you're training for hematite don't just you know be lame and go around replicating sword moves with your heavy weighted club okay it's not a full product it's not full body program for hema so you need to do something more than just swing and twirl the clubs around okay thanks for watching remember to subscribe hit the notification bell leave us some comments or questions and we'll try to cover them next talk to you later [Music]

started to learn the movement and you know you can make those circles in both directions of course but then you want to sort of like graduate to being able to do them with a full grip so with the large heavy clubs most of the moves are based on attacks and by attacks i mean by moves where you cross the midline because that's our strongest uh movement pattern yeah so going away from the midline would be like akin to throwing a dart whereas you know crossing the midline you know you're sword fighting okay boom throwing a spare uh throwing an axe wrestling arm wrestling you know the winner is the guy that crosses the midline this is where we're strong and you lose by going away from the midline so the light clubs open different type of patterns you can do them you know very fancy linking all this kind of stuff but we went from you know the purpose of the indian club that was to train fighters and wrestlers to more of a spectator sport visual performance and this is where the clubs got lighter so you can do new patterns by changing grips you know doing the snakes and all this kind of stuff and it's very available for dexterity and stuff you know but if you're training for a hammer the full grip is the way to go doing the wrist circles with the full grip require more awareness mobility and coordination than using the ring grip okay so you have to practice and when you practice you don't want a stupidly heavy club okay now this club here is our palavendor gamma it's got a 40mm handle so it's still a very thick handle you can see like i'm just closing it here and this is what the forward wrist circle looks like now when we say wrist circle it's actually the club doing a circle because our wrist if you observe now is doing a type of rolling motion okay and the same when i go in reverse so when you practice you know you gotta figure out you gotta imagine you got a wall next to you so the club stays as perpendicular to the ground as possible while your elbow comes in towards the midline as the club drop okay so pay attention to the hand position how much it goes up and down and the displacement towards the midline from my elbow yeah and then you can sort of like do fun stuff and i'm hauling the full grip okay so the full grip we've got two variations you could say you've got the hammer grip yeah perpendicular and this would be used as a resting position or transition position and then you've got the saber grip where the handle of the club is in the proponention of your forearm and kind of like all those moves around there using the saber grip okay so for hema they're the two main groups you need to master worry about and just have a firm grip but relaxed enough to be able to transition between those movements okay also important that you will build some strength by doing wrist circles which also do some direct work to strengthen your wrist and your fingers and your hands in general and again i'll put a link in the description to a circuit where you just follow along to a couple of times a week works great also if you're training for hematite don't just you know be lame and go around replicating sword moves with your heavy weighted club okay it's not a full product it's not full body program for hema so you need to do something more than just swing and twirl the clubs around okay thanks for watching remember to subscribe hit the notification bell leave us some comments or questions and we'll try to cover them next talk to you later [Music]


## Endscreen
    
- [The Ace of Clubs program for heavy clubs, mudgars & clubbells](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zeu62CvL0t0&pp=0gcJCe0AHUcdqGbM)
- [Real military Indian club exercises from 1871](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_Nn6Z8oq4cI)
